It might seem at first that this is simply rude nonsense but once you get the hang of how 'the gang' deal with every single situation in their lives you'll be hooked!Haven't laughed this much for a long time.. just loved it and will continue to love it for many years to come (hopefully)

I don't think I've seen a show that just gets consistently better season by season other than this one. From it's excellent cast of characters; abundance of episodes and ability to always increase the bar, It's Always Sunny remains one of the most boundary-pushing, unapologetic TV shows to ever exist. Sunny's no stranger to tackling difficult subject matters, but it's never out to cause offense and somehow feels incredibly inclusive despite it's bigoted, prejudiced cast. Like a twisted version of Friends, if you were to describe this show's characters to someone without them seeing it, they'd no doubt imagine a group of the most loathsome, delusional people you can imagine. But, after 14 seasons, it's impossible not to fall in love with all the characters and their individual, unusual tendencies.The show follows 5 friends who run a bar, there's Mac, played by Rob McElhenney the show's creator, who is a closeted, religious man who's gone through a number of transformations for the show now, going from thin, to fat, to having the physique of a part-time bodybuilder. Then there's Dennis, a manipulative, sociopathic sexual deviant who's more than likely to be a serial killer. Dee is Dennis' twin sister and a constant recipient of ridicule from the other members of the gang (and if I was forced to pick a favourite, it would probably be her.) Then you have Charlie, the bar's illiterate janitor who lives in squalor and enjoys huffing dangerous inhalants. Last, but far from least, is Danny DeVito's now iconic Frank Reynolds - the misogynistic, rich father to Dennis & Dee, for a few seasons anyway. There's also a bevvy of interesting side-characters, Rickety Cricket & the Waitress are probably the most well-known, and for good reason, but my personal favourite is Artemis, who unfortunately doesn't appear in too many episodes.As the show's gone on, the cast have really found their characters and nail down even the little characterisations like the faces they make and their body language. I think Dennis has come the furthest, he's always been vain, but the exploration of his devious side really made the character step up to the heights of the others - he was my least favourite for a while, now I just love them all. The show's definitely become more unrealistic, but it evolves with the times perfectly from the social issues explores down the technology used in the episodes."McPoyle vs. Ponderosa: Trial of the Century" is one of my favourite episodes. Not only does it have a cameo from Guillermo Del Toro, but it brings together so many side-characters and shows you just how badly the gang have messed up their lives. Another favourite is "The Gang Gives Frank an Intervention," which is one of Frank's funniest episodes. "The Gang broke Dee," "The Gang dances their asses off" and "Time's up for the Gang" are also favourites too name a few more.I don't think any other show out there makes me laugh as much as this, it's the sort of dark humour you don't need to feel bad laughing about, but it's still daring enough to leave you a little shocked. The quotability and references across the internet have cemented this, in my opinion, as a future-classic that I hope will stay on the air forever.

reviews.review_title: one of the best comedies on TV right now.
reviews.content: hah- That isn't really too hard to say since most of the shows on TV are reality shows.Beside the point- this show is so daringly funny. This out there humor is my kind of humor. It's pretty much a non-cartoon version of South Park and to me this is what real humor is like such as great shows like Arrested Development, Seinfield and the first 5 seasons of Friends.It's not too popular, so the show hasn't dumbed itself down to mainstream viewers. I wish it was more popular but if that ruins the quality than I don't mind it getting low ratings.I will stand up and say its better than "The Office." It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia is a show that may not appeal to everyone, due to it's use of crude humor. It is however,to those who are not easily offended, just brilliant. The show centers around five people in Philadelphia who own a bar and get themselves into sticky situations as a result of their personalities.The show is funny as it is primarily character-driven, with the characters who are each extremely obnoxious, rude and self-centered in their own way. The characters instantly frustrate and annoy anyone who comes near them, as well as trying to manipulate each other to do things for their own selfish purposes.These interactions with other people are often the funniest part of the show. When people are around them they find themselves essentially shut out of the conversation, as though the cast is in a different dimension, and end up extremely frustrated by the situation they have found themselves in. The dialogue is also extremely good, focusing on the relatively mundane and the crazy simultaneously. My reference to that would be the "power bottom" scene where they discuss the positions in a homosexual relationship.The comparison of It's always sunny to another good comedy Seinfeld is apt but It's Always Sunny edges out the juggernaut of comedy on it's characters, as Seinfeld's characters are always at least a little bit likable. You at no stage should find It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia's characters likable as they have no shred of human decency. And that is what is quintessentially at the heart of this show and produces the comedy, which was also the case for Seinfeld.It's Always Sunny is one of the great comedies, but not for the easily offended.

I knew about this show for years, watched 2 or 3 episodes on TV, but never got its point. Only after finishing The Office I realized that I can watch a show without liking it. Didn't have many options so I went with IASIP.It's hard to understand this show without watching it for a bit. Characters and their motives are very important and without some background their behaviors probably seem like random violent acts with no purpose. The characters aren't one dimensional, and that's a big plus for me.I also like the colors, camerawork and the atmosphere. It's the perfect dark comedy setup; creates a good balance.I like pretty much everything about it, physical comedy, disgusting and shocking parts, parodies, lots of dad issues, trashy behavior. Even though some things are really dark, gross or weird none of them is overkill. This show doesn't depend on the shock factor.Overall, it's number one in my comedy list now. Great writing, aesthetically pleasing, great cast, multi-layered interesting characters, very absurd situations, clever takes on hot topics like sexism and racism. Sometimes a show goes well until a certain point and then starts to crumble. People start leaving, material runs out or something happens with the writers,characters get old or the plot simply dissappears..It's great to see that at the 13th season the gang is rocking it just like it's the first day.I hope that this show goes on forever, or something close to that.

reviews.review_title: A rare feat in comedy shows
reviews.content: If dark humor is not your thing, turn away. This show employs some of the darkest. If I met any of the main characters in real life, each one would probably be the worst person I've ever met. They are so selfish and twisted that they are all offputting at first, but with the more episodes you watch, it becomes hilarious to see what absurdly messed up schemes they will come up next.I watched the first 12 seasons, and I was quite surprised that the same level of humor was maintained all the way to the final episode, which is an extremely rare feat for comedy shows.

I absolutely love a comedy where people aren't afraid to be/write horrible people. reviews.review_title: Not for everyone, but still genius
reviews.content: Simply put, this is a great new show that a lot of people can and should enjoy. Your parents and some of your older friends may not get the jokes or the humor behind it, but depending on how old you are, you probably will. Rob, Glenn, and Charlie are all great writers and don't try to hard to make the show funny, it just is. They do go overboard with jokes sometimes, but the more you watch it the more you get that that's just how the "gang" is. While watching you can tell a majority of the dialogue is improv, but everyone in the show pulls it off extremely well. The chemistry between the characters is great. I give this show two thumbs up, Roger Ebert style.

reviews.review_title: This show turned out to be....hilarious
reviews.content: This is an updated review from when I watched the first episodes in 2005. Surprisingly from when I first saw this, I am now HOOKED on this comedy, and to be honest, it is now one of the best comedies out there. I am glad FX stayed with it, it has gotten better with each episode. This is the "little comedy that could" and it's fantastic.When this "It's always sunny in Philadelphia" started, it had a very rocky comedy start for me. Then when Danny DeVito was added to the gang the next year, it all began to click. This show is hilariously funny and you will just fall in love with the gang and their exploits at Paddy's Pub. The openings of the show are to die for comically-- and yes, I'll admit my favorite so far is the "Kitten Mittens" opening. (I spelled it right, you have to see it on the show!) The reaction of the gang is what makes this show comedic gold and sets you up for what's to come.Paddy's Pub in Philadelphia is trying to stay afloat; and its curious how they can do so with the staff they have. But that's exactly what makes it stay afloat. The Gang tackles what is going on around them, and what is happening to them and does so in such a childish-realism that you cannot help but laugh and sometimes cheer them on at the same time. Would you want Dee, Frank, Dennis, Charlie and Mac to be your friends? Well, the truth is, you probably have friends that are just the same as they. And that's what makes it fun.

This is one of a few shows that I have watched since it's conception, which was 3 or 4 years ago...I can't quite remember; this fact attests to it's (IASIP's) quality and hilarity. For those of you who have watched It's Always Sunny from the beginning, you will remember the original tag line for the show, "Seinfeld on Crack," ; a spot-on description of this crude yet brilliant series. It fits that description in two key respects; every character in the show is a selfish low- life, (thus the term Seinfeld) and the setting and lifestyle of the characters is an urban, dingy, filthy one, filled with glue-huffing, cat food consumption, beer drinking, anonymous sex.. etc. (thus the term crack). But I hope this seemingly disgusting and crass description of the show does not eschew you from watching it. Quite on the contrary, I hope it encourages you to watch it, because it is funny. Well written and well acted, I never get tired of hearing the five main characters, each one of them victims of a major character flaw, attempt to find their way through conflict and success, and fail every time. Just watch one episode, preferably an early 2nd season one, and I promise you, you will be hooked. Charlie, Mac, Dee, Dennis, and Frank never fail to make whatever they are going through into some ridiculous circumstance that exudes comedy.

reviews.review_title: Like wine in a can, this show has actually gotten better over time

reviews.review_title: One of the best shows to exist

reviews.review_title: Extremely funny in a refreshingly original way.
reviews.content: 'It's Always Sunny''s success comes from it's uniquely edgy and different style of comedy. It achieves this through the brilliantly created group dynamic; a group of shockingly self-serving and callous people- to the point of murder of one another is casually dropped into conversation- manage to create brilliant comedy, due to this fact. Each character is developed so that they have their own unique comic selling point (Charlie's uncomprehendingly disturbed psyche or Dennis' psychotic vanity and obsessive need for control or manipulation, for example). Yet as a group the comic value is furthered as it is although, together, they are horrendously dysfunctional but also darkly harmonic at the same time.Although saying all of this, I think the show does begin to show cracks in it's original and edgy surface around season 8 and these cracks definitely become more noticeable throughout season 9. I think the show's commercial success has negative consequences for it's style. This is because I think the show's selling point or reason for success might have been it's fringe edginess which is achieved through the use of a low budget and focus on characterisation and natural dynamic and atmosphere. I think with the extra resources and money the writers may have steered in the wrong direction, which subsequently meant the comedy seemed more forced and the natural dynamic of the group less prevalent.Although, nonetheless, a brilliant comedy well worth a watch. Don't write it off right away though, once accustomed to the characters, the style of comedy hits home.

Additionally, the writing talent of Rob McElhenney, Glenn Howerton, Charlie Day, and all other writers elevates this show to level that makes me say--a confluence of this much talent is rare, and I will enjoy the ride.This show is the definition of irreverent and dark, and It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia is absolutely not for kids. Aside from that, any adult with an open mind and appreciation for genius comedy should be watching this show.It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia is as close to a perfect comedy as it gets. Enjoy!

reviews.review_title: Like Being Stuck On The Bus Next to THOSE GUYS...for 30 Minutes
reviews.content: OK, I'm glad that people like the show. I truly am. Any show that people can find some joy in watching is okay by me; even if I'm baffled as to why. With a mind-boggling user-rating of 9.2, this might not seem like the best place to offer a dissenting view; but what the heck, I'm a rebel. There's a quote on the home page that says, "Seinfeld on crack." Surely, they jest. The only thing these two shows have in common is that they were filmed.Now, the main problem for me is that I suppose I've never particularly found crude, uncouth, blatantly moronic characters to be particularly funny (Hence why My Name is Earl never really tickled my funny bone). But the biggest problem I had with It's Always Sunny, was that after watching 1 episode from each season, and 2 from the latest season, was that I found it's so painfully unfunny. But what kept nagging me was WHY did I find it so incredibly unfunny. I mean, I know why I find a lame comedy like 2 1/2 Men so painfully unfunny (a laugh track turned up to 10 for every incredibly predictable, lame joke offered would be my starting point. But I digress). I believe great comedy is made up of certain elements. Among the most brilliant comedies in recent TV history that displayed these elements would be shows like Seinfeld, Curb Your Enthusiasm, The Office, and 30 Rock, to name a few. Below is what I think those elements are:1) Top-notch, highly skilled comedians or comic actors in the lead roles.2) Comedic actors who are not only highly-skilled and have perfect timing, but are incredibly interesting to watch (e.g., Jason Alexander, Alec Baldwin, Larry David, Steve Carrell, Michael Richards). It's Always Sunny at least has the great Danny DeVito, but the poor writing wastes his talent. Which leads me to...3) Writing that is so damn clever, with plots lines that tie together so perfectly, and jokes that are so unpredictable that you literally laugh out loud. It's not hard to see why all these shows have been nominated repeatedly for Emmys (along with the Daily Show with Jon Stewart. Another perfectly-crafted comedy led by a highly-skilled comedian).4) Characters and subject matter that is instantly relatable. We've all had moments where we felt like George Costanza or Larry David or Liz Lemon or Jerry Seinfeld, or dealt with a Jack Donaghy. As hard as I searched, I couldn't find ANY of these elements in "It's Always Sunny..." The writing is insipid and reminds you of those two drunk guys at the end of the bar who are convinced they are hilarious after about 12 beers, with punchlines that fall flat. "DUDE! Oh my god, remember that time I farted so loud at that frat party that I set off the house alarm? That was SO FUNNY!"The acting is uneven, with Danny DeVito and Kaitlen Olson doing most of the heavy lifting. Olsen is quite good. As for Rob McElhenney, I give the guy a ton of respect for creating and getting someone to believe in the show enough to buy it, but let's be honest here, the man does not belong in front of a camera. Acting is not his strong suit. Or maybe it's just the poorly written role, but something's gotta give. A show can get away with having characters who are not very bright, provided we care about them. Kramer on Seinfeld may have been an idiot, but he was a lovable idiot, with his heart always in the right place; same goes with the Joey on Friends, or Ted Baxter on the Mary Tyler Moore Show. But the two moronic characters played by McElhenney are Day are so absurdly dumb (as when they throw a box spring, serving as a ladder, out of an empty pool, leaving them stranded; a joke we see a mile away), are so incredibly unlikable that you can't muster the strength to root for them. And yet, they're too boorish and crude to even be fascinated by them.But hey, people seem to dig the show, and that's all that counts. But if you're not a fan of lowbrow comedy, completely lacking in cleverness (as opposed to Family Guy and the Farrelly Brothers movies which are lowbrow, but incredibly clever), this show might not be for you. I'm still trying to square in my head how the same people who recognize the brilliance in shows like Seinfeld and The Daily Show, could also find anything remotely funny here.

Essentially it is a sitcom about four friends that run a bar in Philadelphia. They get into all sorts of zany antics, with very little to no restraint or sense of decency.The stories tend to revolve around one or two main plots, along with some subplots (all four characters tend to have something going on). Eventually all these plots run together, and usually deliver a big-bang of a final punchline to go out on.As for the show itself; the tag-line is pretty accurate ("It's like Seinfeld on crack"), it's the darker cousin of Seinfeld. Whereas Seinfeld focused on little issues like "soft talkers", 'Philadelphia' focuses on things like "tea-bagging" or dating trannies. If you are a fan of both situational, and dark comedy, this is most definitely a show you NEED to see.There are VERY few shows, movies, or stand-up acts that get me to laugh out loud; but 'Philadelphia' seems to get me every time. It's definitely worth a look if you are in the mood for a good laugh.

reviews.review_title: It's Always Sunny In My House!
reviews.content: I admit, I was late to the game. I began watching Sunny when Comedy Central started to air it.Initially, I didn't get it -- at all. The plot lines were all over the place and I couldn't make sense of it. Their crazy antics made me laugh but I was completely lost. And then I experienced it, "The Nightman Cometh"...the episode that changed it all for me! I found everything from the "rape scene" to the marriage proposal so intriguing that I was determined to watch the entire series and piece this Sunny puzzle together.I did my homework. I bought the Six Pack (Seasons 1-5 & "A Very Sunny Christmas"), Season 6 and I even ended up buying the soundtrack. I caught up to it within a few weeks and I am hooked! This is not your typical (boring) cast of characters and the fact that they do not fit the typical (predictable) sitcom mold is what makes it so darn excellent! And to add to the charm of the show, I come to find out that they're all pretty much married to each other in real life! :-) I LOVE this show! They bring a huge smile to my face! I can't wait for Season 8!

reviews.content: It's a really funny and clever show with likable but odd characters.As for why I rate is a 7 as opposed to 9 or 10, first, I'm not a fan of how disturbing it can get sometimes, almost feels like watching Requiem for a Dream with a comedic twist, but I think they've moved away from the worst of that the past few seasons.Second reason is due to how loud it can be. Now that people are used to the opposite, comedy shows that don't have background laughter and often aren't constantly loud, they could also tone down this aspect of the show in my opinion.

Also few shows have as many zany supporting characters and bizarre recurring jokes. From about season 6/7 onwards they start to really experiment with the format having fantasy episodes, parody of another show or genre episodes, one character point of view episodes, minor character episodes which all add up to this being probably the least formulaic sitcom on TV.Loses a couple of points in my rating though as jokes and plots started to feel forced in the last few seasons.

Even Charlie who is always the "founding stone" of the series, now evolved into a more mature version of himself, digging deeper into what makes him the Charlie we know and love. All this was made possible through the above-mentioned excellent writing and the twists that it presented us with during his time in Ireland!Same goes for everyone! Dennis reached new levels of megalomania but also revealed some (hidden until now) emotion. Dee became more confident, Frank more crazy and sentimental at the same time!This season was a delight, so much that i wouldn't blame them if they thought to put an end to it here. reviews.review_title: Comedic genius that guarantees a smile on your face (from now on)
reviews.content: Warning: Spoilers galore . . ."It's Always Sunny" is one of those rare entertainment choices where just thinking about it makes you smile, or even laugh out loud. Remember these names, in no particular order: Charlie Day, Rob McElhenney, Kaitlin Olson, and Glen Howerton, III. They're acting combined with the the 3 guys' writing makes for the funniest show I believe I've ever seen. I pray we've not seen the last of these folks and you ought to, too.When you take some of the most serious issues of today and portray them in ways that bring tears from laughter, genius is somehow involved.I hope to always remember Howerton and Olson on crack, McElhenney's hurt feelings over not having been chosen for molestation by his gym coach, and Charlie "going America all over everybody's ass" which ends up with him writhing in pain from a fork being stuck in his back. With these in my brain, I'm never more than a moment from having a good laugh.If you've ever wondered how Nazis, miracles, abortion (and anti-abortionists), Russian-roulette, welfare, incest, and racism could be explored in an uproariously funny light, then simply watch this show. And like all good satire, you find yourself sometimes wondering if it is in fact, satire---the deviant performances are that convincing. I never thought anyone could develop more self-absorbed characters than Larry David, but the "Sunny" gang gives him a great run for the money.And hat's off to Danny Devito for lending his dark-comedy genius to the mix."Sunny" is not for the faint-of-heart, but it's for everybody else.

reviews.review_title: All-time favorite, best modern sitcom on television
reviews.content: It's Always Sunny is 14 seasons in and still has not lost it's edge. The first and most significant reason this show should be a mandated watch for everyone is that no other sitcom on television right now is managing to make satirical commentary on our society and the mess of American politics in real time the way Sunny does. They've covered every possible political or social issue you can think of from BOTH SIDES (which very few shows are doing). The characters themselves are despicable ridiculous but so entertaining. The show is by far the funniest show on television right now, makes me actually laugh out loud not just exhale heavily through my nose. I cannot stress how amazing this show is - watch it. Sunny isn't afraid of going "there" - wherever that may be. No other modern shows are willing to take the risks in writing or production that Sunny is, and it executes these risks often flawlessly. MUST WATCH.

reviews.content: This "show" is so bad it should be exempted from the Geneva Convention. I am a massive fan of this show but something has gone wrong in series 13.I will attempt an analysis of this;. The show in the past was mostly self contained in its humour, with its own world and own reference points, now suddenly it is bringing in external reference points.It is self-evident that you must never mix genres, to make an issue led programme in a comedic setting does a disservice to both genres and just produces an unsatisfactory result.The gang are older and seem more serious and adult, but the programme in the past was very much based on the inner child and shaking a fist at maturity. The term "reluctant adult" is apposite.I am always wary of fashion trends, gender neutral toilets, me to, times up, racism, immigration, border wall, health fads, etc etc. These are fleeting issues of interest that are not best tackled within this format.In the show we had different levels of intellect and character definition, now they seem all sharp, smart mouthed, etc etc. So the script writing has changed in this respect.Lastly the show primarily was driven by a new ridiculous plan in each episode and how this played out, this was the narrative drive, now as a viewer we are cast adrift and it has descended into a talking shop which can become tedious.I am sure this will come back on track when they connect again with their inner childs.

reviews.review_title: A Darker, More Vulgar How I Met Your Mother
reviews.content: You know exactly what to expect from It's Always Sunny just from reading the episode titles which range from "The Gang Gets Racist" to "Charlie has Cancer" and to my personal favourite "Pop-Pop: The Final Solution". The humour is unapologetically vulgar and is delivered well by its lead characters which are played enthusiastically by their actors. Danny De Vito as Frank Reynolds will be forever remembered by TV lovers for years to come. He manages to play a man who tries to keep order in the group but at the same time is unstable just like the others.The situations that the group find themselves in never feel too exaggerated and are well grounded in reality. The political and social satire is some episodes are hilarious and really show the skill and the genius of the shows writers. It is hard to talk about It's Always Sunny as it is a show that needs to be seen in order to understand the creative and fun aspects that make the show so great.

reviews.review_title: First Six Seasons Are Amazing, but Starts to Go Down Hill After That
reviews.content: Among the first six seasons, I loved almost every episode. Those seasons make for the best comedy of all time. I have probably watched the first six seasons roughly 50 time by now. Most of season 7 is good too, but the quality starts to become noticeably less consistent. By season 8, the show starts to run out of ideas and rehashes events from old episodes. But there is still the odd good episode. Season 9 and onwards is almost all garbage. It just turns into a whole lot of inside jokes and fan service. By season 11, they jump the shark, and hardly anything makes any sense anymore.

reviews.review_title: Easily the Best Comedy on TV
reviews.content: Creative and raunchy, "It's Always Sunny In Philadelphia" is easily the best comedy on the air. The characters are original, the writing is great, and the acting is pretty damn good. Danny DeVito is great, but even the first season (before he joined the cast) was tremendous. There is no single best episode, because every one is equally as laugh-out-loud funny. All of the characters are hilarious: -Mac, the "Brains"; -Dennis, the sleazy, manipulative pretty boy; -Charlie, the lovable idiot; -Frank, the greedy, compulsive gambler; -and Dee, oh, Sweet Dee. I would strongly recommend this show to anyone with a sense of humor. Be warned though, it is NOT for the easily offended.

reviews.review_title: Best Comedy Show on TV, and better than most movies, in the past 10 yrs.
reviews.content: I am really glad a buddy recommended this show to me, years ago. He was like, "If you like South Park and Family Guy, and have twisted sense of humor, you'll love this."He was right. This show is absolutely hilarious, and even when I'm not dying of laughter, the show amuses you with entertainment the whole way through. Many shows, if nothing exciting or climactic is going on, just fail to entertain you or make you think about it much. Sunny never disappoints. Every damn episode is funny to me, and comes up with clever plot lines that showcase the eccentric and narcissistic, if not downright exploitative and psychopathic behaviors/minds of the main characters, and their recurring side characters. Having other continued stories that interact with recurring characters also gives the show plenty of material to draw from. For instance, characters like Cricket and the Lawyer, the molester uncle with small hands, and Artemis, etc. The story continues through these character's lives in many ways, while the main group of stars kind of lives or develops in their own bubble, which gives the show both consistency, and a driving story that still continues into the future. Devito is excellent, and these people are just so ignorant and outrageous, ending up in the funniest and most non-PC situations, that you can't help but revel in the stupidity and hilariousness of the dumpster fire these characters create or run into. This show takes TV comedies to the next level, and blows others out of the water. Most sitcoms and TV comedies are very tame, not daring to risk tackling some of the biggest controversial and hot-button topics of the day, but this crew demolishes all of them in a way that just makes me smile. Sometimes, you just shake your head at the stupidity of the characters--especially Mac and Charlie, and then (only slightly more enlightened) Frank or Dennis have to try to remedy the situation, while constantly making fun of Dee, who you would feel sorry for if it wasn't revealed that she is just as much of a jerk-off as the males, if not more shallow. Other shows also push a lot of political propaganda or their brand of morals for left or right wing views; this show makes a lot of good points about all of it, without preaching and acting like an afterschool special sobfest or Ad Council message for kids. It just gives you a brutal, no-holds- barred look at what can happen when wacky, egocentric morons encounter any number of these issues and fall into disaster.
This show is amazing, it has great humor, great jokes. And even better actors.

reviews.review_title: Runs out of actual humour by Season 9
reviews.content:
The series starts out pretty great: a group of 4 friends (including a pair of siblings) who work at a bar they own get embroiled in various unusual scenarios related to certain hot-button issues, mostly by their own doing, due to their varied quirks, low inhibitions and questionable sense of morality.As season came after season, hardly anything remains of that solid foundation by the conclusion of Season 9, where I stopped watching (with 5 more seasons ahead of me). The character of Frank, who joins the gang on a permanent basis in Season 2, is too oddball not to take the series in a way more whimsical, less grounded direction. The gang's doings become increasingly more absurd, scattershot, moronic and villianous as time goes on; their characters grow from loveable exaggerations of some people we might know or even be to being the dumbest and most immoral people on the globe. Any sense of consequences is lost.The series loses sight of its focus on hot-buttons issues, ups the dose of gross-out toilet humour and slowly devolves into a live-action Family-Guy-esque. Meanwhile, its attempt at maintaining continuity result both in an immovable status quo (that sinks a lot of episodes but boosts some others that try to mix things up) and in a vast roster of supporting characters, many of whom you'd think are too one-note to reappear or for anyone to care to see them again.That degradation does not have a linear character, as Seasons 5 and 6 harken back to Season 1 (or even 2) every now and then, or try new things that land - but are promptly forgotten. And while good episodes can still be found later on, there's too much muck to rake through.In the end, I've certainly enjoyed a lot of the series, and the acting is brilliant with amazing delivery for more than a few great lines; and a lot of the plots are very imaginative and truly hilarious - at a certain point, the diminishing returns have to be recognised however. The series just doesn't have fuel to last that long even without pulling the engine out on the go - but it's still screeching along, god knows why.My ratings by season:
S1: 6
S2: 5
S3: 4
S4: 4
S5: 5
S6: 6
S7: 3
S8: 4
S9: 3

reviews.review_title: More real than reality television could ever hope to be

The North Korea episode was funny, but bordered between stereotypical and full out 1970's Asian-style racism. 20 year old looking girl with a hybrid Vietnamese-Chinese accent is really a 12 year old North Korean. Ha. Ha. I get it. But in all fairness, Mr. Kim was great. Also, the relationship between the story and North Korean politics were well executed.Most of the episodes border on absurdity and full-out misogyny, which I wouldn't have a problem with if the characters were more than one dimensional. No actor or actress show any motivation for their character beyond caricature. It felt like they were just a bunch of pals bouncing lines off of each other - each of their characters could be summarized in one sentence.The only one who acts really well is Danny De Vito, although he acts like a monster reminiscent of his penguin past. Self depravity can only go so far in comedy.So there were great episodes, funny ones, and forgettable ones. This is the type of show I would play on Hulu while I'm eating dinner, but I wouldn't go out of my way to watch it. I might buy the dick towel, though.

This place is confusing enough.

reviews.review_title: All for Laughs, Strongly Character-Development Based, Ripe Dark Comedy
reviews.content: What starts out as being just a very pleasant, funny current show with a nice original vibe to it eventually turns into one of the strongest comedy shows in modern American TV.A gang of worthless, completely broken, nihilistic individuals; each one more messed up than the next in his own way; wreak havoc on everything they touch and everyone unfortunate enough to cross their paths.The show is strong on many levels. The combined and distinct humors of Charlie, Mac and Dennis as writers, coupled with a very strong and coherent character development aspect, and the ability for the show to come up with new ideas and story lines and (somehow) not feel blatantly stupid and redundant despite the VERY minimalistic main plot... all makes for a very steady foundation that allows for plenty of seasons to be binged through seamlessly.There's a difference between what the first couple of seasons feel like, and what seasons 7 and 8 feel like, and then what the last few seasons feel like... but there's a consistent quality to each episode, and they manage not to repeat themselves or go crazy just to remain relevant at all.The supporting cast is great too: the mothers, Danny Devito, "sweet" Dee, and the character "Cricket" in particular is brilliant - with the funniest scenes usually involving any of the McPoyle family members (and milk).On a slightly deeper note: the show may come across as too dark at times with its humor, but it seems as one gets up in age to where they're closer to the guys in the show's age, it's just comedy for the sake of comedy so there's definitely a certain cynicism about it all and the moralities drawn from the episodes are quite brutal: people are hopeless and hopelessly unchangeable, bad habits never break and life is tough and unfair so you might as well waste yourself away... but it's all for the laughs in the end.A solid 8/10.

reviews.review_title: Greatest TV show of all time (IMO)
reviews.content: I've loved this show from the very first episode. I've watched every episode of every season, every blooper reel, every commentary multiple times. I love Charlie, Dee, Dennis, Mac and Frank all equally. It's the same way Seinfeld fans loved Jerry, George, Kramer and Elaine all equally. The supporting cast in Sunny are also loved and always bring the "lols" the same way Seinfeld had George's parents, Newman etc. Don't get me wrong, two completely different shows, but one thing is undeniable, they are both bloody amazing and Sunny for me, will go down as the greatest television viewing of my short life thus far.

I believe this is a show that you will absolutely love or absolutely hate. If you look at the number of reviews, almost all of them are either 9-10 stars or 1-2 stars. I'd say that's a fair assessment. The appreciation of the humor of the show is personality-dependent, and I'm one who greatly appreciates it. I will say it took 4 or 5 episodes before I really started to feel the groove. But once I did, its been true love ever since. There is also a lot of great 80s and 90s songs in many of the episodes that's a big plus for me!I didn't start watching until s12e1 and within a week or two had watched every previous show, all out of sequence. In retrospect, that was a great approach. The characters never really changed (with the exception of Danny DeVito after the end of s2). I won't elaborate for any newcomers wishing to form their own opinion.As for recurring characters, SHOCKING change! I first met Rickety Cricket in s6, the 2nd Sunny show I watched. I didn't see his beginning (I think s2e7 The Gang Exploits a Miracle) until watching s6-11 first. My mind was blown! And I think at that point, I truly appreciated the writing of the show!When I try to tell others about an episode, I hear the words and think this sounds terrible...and I suppose the topics are. But the writing and cast are so genius with the delivery, they make taboo subjects hilarious while making you look at your own attitude about the subject matter. As warped as their attitudes can be, there is always one if them that is the voice of reason.After watching all of the episodes several times now, I still laugh out loud watching the mannerisms and facial expressions of the cast in the background that I didn't notice the first watch.The recurring characters are phenomenal as well. Artemis, Cricket, the McPoyles, Waitress, Gail the Snail, Mrs. Kelly, Mrs. Mac, the attorney, Zee, and the busboy are just some of those characters that add to the depth of the show. There is not one character that doesn't embody the personality to perfectly drive a point home.For those who are looking for a "cheerful atmosphere" or "feel good endings", this show is NOT for you.If you're looking an honest perspective of real attitudes of mankind, as twisted as they are. You'll probably appreciate the show.Great first watch episodes (IMO):
s3e9 Sweet Dee is Dating a Retarded Person
s9e10 The Gang Squashes Their Needs
s11e5 Mac & Dennis Move to the Suburbs
s9e1 The Gang Broke Dee
s4e7 Who Pooped the Bed

s6e8&9 should be watched together and any episode with Lethal Weapon in the titles4e13 Night man Cometh is awesome, but I don't think it can be appropriately appreciated without knowing a little about the characters.I hope this helps any newbies find their own love for this creatively genius show.

This is the only sitcom that's ever been in the same league as "Seinfeld," but they are much more hit-and-miss/erratic (even in their best seasons) than "Seinfeld" in its prime. Even after Larry David left, "Seinfeld" maintained a consistent standard of (cartoonish) quality. Later seasons of "It's Always Sunny" have notably declined a bit, though the show is still worth watching, and it may rebound, sheerly depending on the writing. It's just the old "be more genius" problem. Like "Seinfeld," the best episodes of "Sunny" fully embraced cartoonishness after briefly flirting with pseudo-realism. Content is much more depraved, "South Park"-esque and sociopathy-based, as well as "alcoholic," if that could inform a comedy genre (it does here.) A recurring theme is two characters being so disgusting that they collect and root in filth and garbage, to the point of stuffing open wounds with stray "trash" as first aid. And habitually wondering the sewers naked. The writers seemed determined to take the "vaguely unlikeable/selfish" characterizations of "Fawlty Towers," "The Office," "Curb Your Enthusiasm" and "Seinfeld" to the extreme. These are the most repulsive, vain, immoral, unlikable characters ever depicted in a sitcom, and most of the best plots draw on very strong characterizations along those lines. Like John Cleese said, "they make you laugh, so you think that you like them." Kaitlin Olson certainly portrays the best comic female character since "Elaine." Her selfish efforts to have a surrogate for "easy money," or make her pathetic life into "Sex in the City" draw on a petty, braindead femaleness that most dumb sitcoms don't touch. Even "Sunny" was going to make her into a scold, at first, until the writers realized how funny and fresh a morally-depraved woman character pursuing her feeble dreams could be. My favorite episodes include "The Gang Gives Frank an Intervention," "The Gang Solves the Mortgage Crisis," "The Gang Gets Invincible" and "Mac and Dennis: Manhunters," but your mileage may vary.

Sunny has proved to be an outstandingly original and singularly unforgettable television experience. Though featuring live action characters, Sunny retains a surreal and cartoonish quality to its physical comedy and absurd, albeit original and hilarious story lines thus far limited to animated series such as "Family Guy" and "South Park".Sunny follows the lives of four career slackers - Charlie, Mac, and siblings Dennis and Dee, along with the second season debut of their father Frank, outstandingly portrayed by veteran Danny DeVito. The gentlemen (used in its loosest possible sense) of the cast, excluding DeVito, are the sick and twisted minds behind the writing and direction of the series.I could offer quips and scenarios from the show until blue in the face but suffice it to say Sunny will eventually get around to offending your ethnic group, religion, or general sensibilities and values. But it will do so in such a singularly hilarious and seldom dramatic way that you won't consider for a moment taking it personally. Sunny is strictly for those of us who appreciate outstanding, yet comically absurd writing. Realistically, our beloved protagonists would be serving 15 to life for the multiple felonies they commit each episode, and their obvious credit ratings would prohibit them from any manner of private property ownership, much less the Irish pub they are the proprietors of in the series.Sunny delivers consistent, cutting-edge humor in each episode. Thusly, you need only give it half an hour. If you haven't been driven to laughter nearly to the point of tears - move on. For those of you like myself that have, sit back and wonder what the hell they could possibly do to top it in the following week. They haven't disappointed to this point.

reviews.review_title: A Disturbing Look at Modernity (A review of the first 7 seasons)
reviews.content: I never really got It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia. Having been around people watching it I had seen many random episodes and was not particularly impressed. The absolute depravity really bothered and disturbed me at first, but I eventfully grew to love how this assortment of broken humans have found a family in each other.There is something about how they can find meaning and acceptance together, despite all the blows society has dealt them. How they remain an unshakable family despite their extreme nihilism and egotism. They may still be despicable human beings, but their constructed family makes them better people than they would be otherwise.It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia has many similarities to previous classical sitcoms like Friends and Seinfeld. But where Friends and Seinfeld glorifies the modern city life of singles, It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia lays bare the deformity of their value system. The show clearly makes fun of nihilistic and egotistical culture; It shows the results of greed, a man who has everything but lives in squalor eating cat food and huffing paint. It shows how the self love of a young man and woman makes it impossible for them to ever find anyone else to love them. It shows how a brave single mother was unable to supply a environment conductive to raising a child. It shows how bare and meaningless a life filled with with nothing but meanness self-fulfillment is. It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia is not The Walton's or Road to Avonlea, but at its core is the family. Charlie, Dennis, Mac, Dee, and Frank are hopelessly broken people without any chance of redemption, but they survive because of the stability of their impromptu family.

reviews.review_title: Addicted to the best sense of humor..
reviews.content: ..all the contributors to this series, yes they Definitely are addicted to the best sense of humor. This series overcomes the boundaries of a traditional stereotypical American writing type. That is one of the main reasons it has fans all over the world, like myself. The cast has an extremely realistic bond in the plot, in a way that you really think you are watching a weird, unconventional and unbelievably hilarious group of people that could live nearby.. If you really want to watch something witty, truly funny and most of all unique then this is your chance. Thank you Rob, Glenn, Charlie, Kaitlin and dearest Danny for all the laughter you are giving us.

Absolutely one of a kind , the way the cast bounce of each other is fantastic. Charlie day is brilliantly funny as per but for me the introduction of Danny devito was the greatest move ever he plays Frank Reynolds perfectly, I couldn't stop laughing at his antics. Everything from the traditional Irish setting to the wacky characters this series will keep you laughing throughout. Sweet dee did my head in quite alot with her stupid accents and sound effects at first, made me dislike the actress but after watching some of Kaitlin Olson's interviews it just goes to show how well she plays the character as she portrays the annoying twin sister very well and is unlikely this in person. Once I watched one i couldn't stop until I finished all seasons in just over a week. Never normally rate these things but this was so brilliant I felt compelled to share how funny this show is.
